qas.question: These ancient hunter-gathers followed what path in pursuit of game?
Between what ice sheets were the corridors located?
What other way could they have crossed on to this continent?
Hunter-gatherers traveled along iced corridors how many years ago?
Big-game hunters cam from Asia into South America over what bridge?
Using advanced boats, they also could have migrated down the Pacific to where?
A land bridge from Asia into South America existed how many years ago?

context: Evidence suggests big-game hunter gatherers crossed <b3_0>the Bering<b3_0/> Strait from Asia (Eurasia) into North America over <b5_0>a land bridge<b5_0/> (Beringia), that existed between <b7_0>47,000–14,000 years ago<b7_0/>. <b4_0>Around 18,500-15,500 years ago<b4_0/>, these hunter-gatherers are believed to have followed herds of now-extinct Pleistocene megafauna along <a0_0>ice-free corridors<a0_0/> that stretched between the <a1_0>Laurentide and Cordilleran<a1_0/> ice sheets. Another route proposed is that, either on foot or using <a2_0>primitive boats<a2_0/>, they migrated down the Pacific coast to <b6_0>South America<b6_0/>.
